The invisible man 2020 is a good Scifi horror movie, it has tension, psychological horror, and a standout performance from Elizabeth Moss, that makes you really want to root for her character throughout the runtime of the movie. It tells the story of Elizabeth Moss's character escaping from the clutches of her abusive boyfriend, and two weeks later finding out that her boyfriend had commited suicide, but later on she finds out that she is being stalked and harrased by someone that she cannot see. Leigh Whanell has really put his stamp on this project. This movie builds tension, and actual scary thoughts and scenarios, executed greatly and effectively by Leigh Whanell and his crew.

PROS:
-Amazing cinematography
-Stand-out performance from Elizabeth Moss
-Plot twist makes the story a lot more interesting
-Has that sense of uncertainty of is the Invisible Man there or not, and if Elizabeth Moss's character has gone insane or not
-A modern take on the old Universal monster Invisible Man

CONS: [Minor spoilers ahead]
-Some plot inconveniences like how is the invisible man able to catch up to the heroine so quickly, another example would be at the ending like she killed him with a knife right, but then she appears without the suit right after immediately, like I'm pretty sure putting on and removing the suit takes a little bit more time than that, and then when she moans his death, the police officer rushes over, and he sees her all packed up and ready to go, come on how fast does she move? The speed of light like bro come on
-Some parts of the movie are a little bit stretched out and kinda boring, I had to pause for a bit and do something then come back and finish the movie for a better experience, which I don't normallydo, what I normally do is I watch the movie from start to finish continuously, but just when it's starting to get boring the twist comes in and brings me right back on board with the movie.

Overall The Invisible Man is a good horror Sci-fi flick, that has excellent built up tension, amazing cinematography, a strong female lead in Elizabeth Moss, and a pretty interesting twist to round it all off. I give Invisible Man a 7/10, I did not enjoy it as much, found some parts boring, but it's still really good, and I would recommend this movie to people who are looking for a modern take on a horror classic, or people who are looking for good underrated films that will probably fly under the radar, Leigh Whannell is now on my directors to watch list.

I was not hugely excited to see this. The previews looked good but it was hard to tell if it was going to offer anything new. I was never so happy to have expectations shattered, I was on the edge of my seat the whole time until the credits started. The tension building is comparable to the best horror films ever made and the jump scares were all original and inventive, they not only made me jump but they all left me terrified for some time after because they all came when you'd least expect them to and all had horrible ramifications. The acting was superb, the character development, complexity and like-ability for the lead was incredible. You genuinely liked her and was rooting for her the entire time, admiring her intelligence. Even the character development of the young girl was better than most film leads. The twists had me genuinely shocked and an ending that could be looked at as unsure of what really happened or you were completely sure. It was one of the best horror thrillers I have seen in some time and that includes all the other great horror films that have come out in the last few years.

Leigh Whannell's "The Invisible Man" is an intense, gripping and terrifying psychological thriller that puts a fresh spin on the well-worn horror genre. With his latest feature, writer/director Leigh Whannell has crafted a captivating film about a woman haunted by an invisible entity. It's the filmmaker's first attempt to bring a classic movie monster to the big-screen, but he pulls it off seamlessly. Using haunting cinematography, Whannell draws viewers into the life of a mentally disturbed woman. From intimate close-ups to lingering long shots, the cinematography immerses viewers in the film's eerie setting. In terms of acting, the entire ensemble is at the top of its game. Elizabeth Moss delivers one of the best performances of her career as Cecilia Kass. With riveting expressions, she conveys the fear, angst and desperation of an abused woman haunted by an invisible entity. The supporting cast, which includes the scene-stealing Aldis Hodge, is also worthy of recognition. Although "The Invisible Man" is undeniably terrifying, ultimately it is not a flawless film. At over two hours, it is slightly long and overstays its welcome. Moreover, it builds to an ambiguous ending that doesn't entirely work. Nevertheless, fans of the horror genre will definitely enjoy "The Invisible Man" and so will movie-goers seeking enthralling entertainment. At a time when strong female protagonists are rarely seen in horror films, it's a visible reminder of the enduring power of female-led stories.

One of the highly recommended thriller film of 2020! The Invisible Man is a science fiction and suspense thriller based on old Hollywood material but retooled and retold in a different approach. At first I thought is was based or remake of Hallow Man (2000) which has the same premise but not as it goes to stand on its own story. The Invisible Man is a proof that suspense and thriller film with old material story could work again given with the right screenplay, acting and direction. The story was refresh and infused with modern takes that we've never seen in other thriller films. Lead star Elisabeth Moss carried the film with her acting from a fearful and vulnerable to a brave and fighter Cecilia Kass. The Invisible Man did not rely heavily on jump scares trope but there are some scenes that you cannot resist but to jump and even scream! It heavily relied on tension and atmosphere to induced horror and thrill which I like on this movie. I had mixed feelings with the ending - it's either needs further explanation or it wasn't an impactful enough to leave the last 15 minutes that way. Yet, The Invisible Man is still one of my highly recommended film of 2020.

Leigh Whannell's movie "The Invisible Man" is quite interesting. It's a mysterious movie full of suspense which sometimes can get very disturbing to look at, but you'll find yourself having the need to know what's next. 

This science fiction horror film and its numerous unexpected scenes reminds you of a classic original Hollywood horror movie, although, it has its own touch that makes it special. The principal photography of the movie was set in Sydney (Australia); however, various scenes were also shot in Kiama and Gerringong. The film shows the story about a woman who ran away from her abusive and rich boyfriend who apparently committed suicide later, but the problem is when she starts to feel him closer than ever after his death.

Set on Australia in the present The invisible Man antagonist is a crazy businessman and scientist called Adrian Griffin who faked his own suicide and afterward utilizes his capacity to be invisible to threaten his previous girlfriend (the protagonist, Cecilia Kass), who chooses to defy the undetectable man herself after the police didn't trust her story.

There's no doubt that "The invisible man" it's a complete success since it has earned seven time its production budget just in its global opening weekend. It must be mentioned that there are a couple of impeccable good performances, an example, the role played by the only 16 years old Storm Reid who had to dissimulate to scuffle with someone who wasn't even there, she did an amazing job.

I personally think that casting Elizabeth Moss as the protagonist was probably the best decision for this film, is astonishing how she accomplished to make Adrian's presence feel so real when he wasn't even present when filming the scene, its doubtless that this type of work It's  truly requesting and stressful; it's a tremendous quantity of effort that she needs to give.

Honestly the ending was very predictable and kind of cliché, it ended like every other revenge film , but at the same time there's nothing wrong with a good old blood and scary movie, however it's disappointing to watch a film this well made and phenomenally casted to end up without a transcendental ending.

One of the most remarkable things about this movie is the way it plays with your mind which is very curious since this is the specialty of the antagonist, you spend almost the entire movie wondering if there really is an invisible man or Cecilia is just traumatized and going crazy, this fact makes you think that the problem is not really that Cecilia is not able to see Adrian, the real issue is that people who can't manipulate you tend to manipulate the way other people see you

Finally, I truly recommend for you to watch the movie, learn about the mysteries of science and assure a good time.

Providing a modern-day retelling of the timeless H.G. Wells story, The Invisible Man is a film I'm not sure I would call an out-and-out horror. It certainly has its horror elements, such as a seemingly unstoppable killer, a lead who's constantly in danger and several tense fight sequences, but the film is more of a psychological thriller about an abusive relationship and the effects of obsession and control. Elizabeth Moss, no stranger to acting out intense situations, gives us a very competent lead who shows great resourcefulness and bravery in the bleakest of situations, rather than being the kind of screaming, useless idiot these films are usually populated with. The films direction and cinematography create a lot of wide, pulled back shots, forcing the viewer to examine the very edges of the screen for a killer we know is there, but can never see. It's a film built entirely on the unknown, and the terror lies in our inability to see what's truly happen. It's a relief not to be sitting through yet another jump scare fest, which is what most modern horror films are aspiring to be, sadly, but to instead be drawn into a conflict that keeps on escalating. It takes a story from more than a century ago, gives it a modern twist but stays true to its original spirit. Rich in atmosphere and dripping with suspense, The Invisible Man builds a solid foundation for what looks to be a promising cinematic future.

I love the stories of the invisible man, and this is certainly a different take of the story.  Rather than embracing the opportunity for effects and dark comedy, this film limits the effects severely and goes for straight terror.  The brilliant thing about the way it is shot is the sense of paranoia it creates.  I can't remember the last time I've watched a movie this closely.  The film will do things such as move away from frame of a character a little early or a little late, or hold onto an area where there seems to be nothing.  Look closely and you might see a chair or something that's slightly indented.  Other times the camera will move and you won't know if it's a POV shot or just a normal camera movement shot.  It's not established, but this isn't a mistake, it just adds to the sense of paranoia the movie is creating.  There's a few jump scenes, and even a moment when I actually gasped, but for the most part it's all about the building sense of tension and dread and it does so perfectly.  Telling it in a story of an abusive relationship that feels all too real with Elizabeth Moss absolutely killing it as a woman who seems insane but only we know isn't.  If I have a criticism of the movie, it's that once the s*** really hits the fan in the third-act, it does start to become standard monster movie action formula to a degree.  It still holds a lot of the tension, but not as much as it starts to devolve into more violence and action.  Still for how tense the rest of the film is there is a sense of catharsis to this, and in its final moments it does return to form.  Overall this is a great reboot of a classic story.  If this is the way Universal is going with it's monsters now, dropping that Dracula Untold and Tom Cruise Mummy crap, I'm all in.

The Invisible Man is one of those rare films that remakes an age old horror film successfully for modern audiences. I won't go into spoilers here, but this is a great horror film. They manage to twist the narrative onto the woman and her struggles to survive a violent relationship. This is relevant in so many areas and the filmmaker has started to find his feet with Blumhouse. Insidious Chapter 3 was a tough act to follow after James Wan, but Upgrade and now The Invisible Man are giant leaps forward. Consider the budget of these films are much lower and allow for creativity and lower studio interference. This is one reboot that works and establishes itself with topical subjects of our era. A must-see. 22/03/2020

The Invisible Man was an awesome movie. It was extremely suspenseful, creepy, and intense at times. It also had one of the most shocking and unexpected scenes that I have seen in a while! The plot was very intriguing and it had a great twist! The pacing was great too; it didn’t feel too long or too short. The cinematography was perfect for a movie like this as most scenes had lots of empty space, making the audience search for “the invisible man” and wonder where he is hiding in the frame. The editing and special effects were great (I still don’t know how some of the scenes were filmed/edited so well) and so was the score. I loved how the music escalated during the final scene of this film. So great! Elisabeth Moss...damn she was good! She should be nominated for an Oscar for her performance. Everyone else acted very well too, but she really surprised me! Honestly, I don’t have anything negative to say about this one. Leigh Whannel is on a roll! Upgrade was excellent but this movie is on a whole new level.

I was sooo looking forward to an invisible man movie. Cinematography was great, effects are spot on, and the score really helps to bend that physiological thriller mindset. Moss (Cecilia) plays the part of abuse victim convincingly, though she also plays the part of helpless abuse victim very well in other movies. Sometimes infuriatingly so. The plot, however, just pure blows. My eyes constantly rolled to the back of my skull, while my mind quietly screamed "for fucks sake!" Who the hell invents invisibility, somehow fakes their own death, and then haunts their ex for pure shits an giggles? Answer: obviously, psychotic alpha dominant males in a #MeToo environment with nothing better to do. Every step of the way the story allows itself gaping holes in order to push this damsel in distress victim narrative, while yet every other actor is too wrapped in their one track mindset to question what's going, which unfortunately robs the movie of any real sense of quality or depth.

Somehow it's gotten great reviews... and on a technical level I'd say, well, yeah! Well deserved. But the reality is, all the director/story writer has done to build tension is to tie up a coherent story with incomprehensible knots that a child would spot, which really only makes for a frustrating viewing, because it's so frustratingly unintelligent, less physiological thriller, and more physiologically demanding for you to sit in your seat and bear out this kind of torture.

If you're a fan of the SAW movies, fear not... there's a slight peppering of gore and plot twists that might blow your mind. I was too pissed off with how dumb everything was for these lick shots to really pay off, and, really, it just annoyed me even more that these shallow "plot twists" were obviously the crux that this entire clusterfuck of storytelling was supposed to hang on.

It's a shame, then, because technically the thing had merit. But unfortunately the characters were too one dimensional (not their fault), and the whole thing was propped up with a framework made to make the story "work." It didn't, in my opinion.

This is a well-acted quality suspense movie.  However, there isn't anything unique or different enough about it that will keep it from fading into the landscape of mediocrity as it ages.  The biggest oddity about this film was the duality of the special effects (or maybe lack thereof...) To put it a simpler way, there were scenes where it truly looked like someone was fighting an invisible person and others where it truly looked like the actor was merely writhing around on the ground by themselves.  Unfortunately, when the latter moments happen, it deflates much of the tension that was so skillfully constructed up to that point (I'd be interested to know how those scenes were actually filmed--whether an actor was digitally removed, or never there to begin with, or a mix of both...) Another thing I took major issue with was the ending.  While the story really isn't that complicated, it doesn't need to be:  A girl thinks her obsessive and abusive ex-boyfriend faked his death and is terrorizing her using secret technology he developed as part of his job.  So eventually, we find out whether she's right or wrong.  90% of it is largely predictable.  That's OK as long as it's executed well.  For all intents and purposes, it is.  But that last 10%...oh boy.  That last 10% is so arbitrarily tacked on and there's no reason it needs to be there, nor is there anything in the film that the viewer can connect back to and be like "Ohhhhh...right!  The blue shoelaces!" (or whatever, just using that as a random example, not as one from the movie).  There were other options they could have chosen that would have been MUCH stronger.  Despite these flaws, it's still a solid movie, but not one that will be remembered for years to come.
